English for International Researchers
Text and Tasks

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

There are three types of articles in English: 

  • Definite article (the): used for things we know about or which are specific.
  • Indefinite article (a/an): used for things that are intro­duced for the first time or not specific. An is used before words that start with a vowel sound.
  • Zero article (-): used for unspecified uncountable nouns,  plural nouns, abstract nouns, and proper nouns.

[1] THE Theory of Relativity states that nothing can travel faster than THE speed of light in a vacuum. 

[2] - Pascal's principle states that a contained pressurized fluid will exert - pressure equally in all - directions.

[3] - Physics is THE most fundamental and all-inclusive of THE sciences.

[4] THE Bohr model is a planetary model of THE atom.

[5] - Richard Feynman helped to discover THE reasons that led to THE Challenger space shuttle disaster.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

[1] In the structure noun 1 + of + noun 2, noun 2 is usually defining noun 1, which should be preceded by the.

[2] Zero article (-) is used with proper names (Pascal), unspecified abstract nouns (pressure), and unspecified plural nouns (directions).

[3] Zero article is used with school subjects (physics, mathematics, biology). We use the with superlatives (the most, the highest, etc.). We use the with plural nouns to refer to different members of a class (the sciences, the Poles, etc.).

[4] Bohr is a name (Niels Bohr, 1885-1962) but here it is being used as an adjective, to define model. Note that some names have adjective forms, e.g. Descartes / Cartesian, Gauss / Gaussian. A singular noun preceded by the (e.g. the atom) represents a class of things (atoms in general).

[5] We use zero article with names of people, unless we specify the person ('do you mean the Richard Feynman who won the Nobel Prize?). Nouns in defining relative clauses with that are often preceded by the. Challenger is being used here as an adjective, to define space shuttle disaster.

Exercise 2
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Read and complete.

Born in 1642, [1] the English physicist and philosopher Sir Isaac Newton revolutionized [2] the world's understanding of [3] the physical universe with his three laws of motion.

Newton's first law of motion states that all [4] - objects continue in [5] a state of rest or at uniform speed in [6] a straight line unless acted upon by [7] a nonzero net force. This property of [8] - matter to remain at rest or in motion is known as - [9] inertia. Newton's first law is often termed [10] the law of [11] - inertia.

Newton's second law states that [12] the acceleration of [13] an object is equal to the net force acting upon [14] the object divided by its mass.

Newton's third law of motion states that whenever one object exerts force on [15] a second object, [16] the second object exerts [17] an equal and opposite force on [18] the first.

Adapted from Newton's 3 Laws of Motion by Engineering Technology Simulation Learning Videos, licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

[1] Isaac Newton is famous - therefore he needs no introduction. This is why we say he is the English physicist, not just an English physicist.

[2] Even though there may be other worlds (and moons, and suns, etc.) it is obvious from the context that we are talking about our world, which is unique.

[3] Physical is an adjective that defines which universe we are talking about.

[4] Objects in general do not require an article (zero article).

[5] In a state of rest is a phrase meaning at rest.

[6] There are many possible straight lines. Here we refer to an unspecified member of that class.

[7] There are many nonzero net forces. Here we refer to an unspecified member of that class.

[8] Matter here is an uncountable noun.

[9] Inertia here is an uncountable noun.

[10] In the structure noun1 + of + noun2, noun2 is usually defining noun1, which should be preceded by the.

[11] Inertia here is an uncountable noun.

[12] There are many objects. Here we refer to an unspecified member of that class.

[13] Net force is defined (acting on...)

[14] This object is introduced for the first time. An is used in front of vowel sounds.

[15] This second object is being introduced for the first time.

[16] This object has been introduced, so future references to the same object will be to the object.

[17] This object has been introduced, so future references to the same object will be to the object.
Exercise 3
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Read and complete.

In [1] - 1965, Gordon Moore  predicted that [2] the number of [3] - transistors that could be fit on [4] a chip would double every year.

In [5] the 1970s, he revised his estimate to say that [6] - processing power would double every two years. This prediction is known as [7] - Moore's Law.

It turns out that [8] - other important measurements have also shown roughly [9] the same doubling behavior, such as [10] - processor speed and [11] the amount of [12] - memory that fits in [13] a computer.

This trend is important because it means that [14] - computer scientists not can not only tackle more complex problems more efficiently, but also plan their projects based on expected future processing speeds.

Adapted from Beauty and Joy of Computing by University of California, Berkeley and Education Development Center, Inc. licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Exercise 4
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Read and complete (note that in some cases more than one answer is possible).

It is well known that there are at least 10 times more bacteria than there are human cells in [1] the body, and that [2] the majority of those bacteria are found in [3] the human gastrointestinal tract (Savage 1977).

Throughout [4] the history of [5] - microbiology, - most human studies have focused on [6] the / - disease-causing organisms found on or in people; fewer studies have examined the benefits of [7] the / - resident bacteria.

As noted in [8] - reviews by Relman and Falkow (2001) and Relman (2002), [9] the endogenous flora of [10] the human body are poorly understood.

Following [10] the publication of [11] the human genome sequence in 2001 (International Human Genome Sequencing Consortium 2001; Venter et al. 2001), Julian Davies argued that although completing [12] the human genome sequence was [13] a / the “crowning achievement” in [14] - biology, it would be incomplete until [15] the synergistic activities between [16] - humans and [17] - microbes are understood (Davies 2001).

Relman and Falkow (2001) called for [18] a “second human genome project” that “would entail [19] a comprehensive inventory of microbial genes and genomes at [20] the four major sites of [21] - microbial colonization in [22] the human body: [23] the mouth, gut, vagina, and skin.”

Adapted from The NIH Human Microbiome Project by The NIH HMP Working Group, licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

In [8] you may choose whether you want to talk about disease-causing organisms found on or in people (in general), or the disease-causing organisms found on or in people (defined).

In [9], you may choose whether you want to talk about resident bacteria (in general) or the resident bacteria (defined by the context as living in the human body).

In [16], you may choose whether this was a crowning achievement (one of many) or the crowning achievement (unique). In the original text, the authors write that this was "a crowning achievement."
Exercise 5
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Read and complete (note that in some cases more than one answer is possible).

In clinical settings, - light microscopes are THE most commonly used microscopes. There are two basic types of preparation used to view specimens with A/THE light microscope: - wet mounts and - fixed specimens.

THE simplest type of preparation is A/ THE wet mount, in which A/ THE specimen is placed on A/THE slide in A drop of liquid. Some specimens, such as A drop of urine, are already in liquid form and can be deposited on A/ THE slide using A dropper.

Solid specimens, such as A skin scraping, can be placed on A/ THE slide before adding A drop of liquid to prepare A/ THE wet mount. Sometimes THE liquid used is simply - water, but often - stains are added to enhance -/THE contrast. Once -/ THE liquid has been added to THE slide, a coverslip is placed on - top and THE specimen is ready for examination under THE microscope.

THE second method of preparing specimens for - light microscopy is fixation. THE “fixing” of A sample refers to THE process of attaching cells to A slide. Fixation is often achieved either by heating (heat fixing) or chemically treating THE specimen.

In addition to attaching A/ THE specimen to A/ THE slide, fixation also kills -/THE microorganisms in THE specimen, stopping their movement and metabolism while preserving THE integrity of their cellular components for observation.

Adapted from 2.4 Staining Microscopic Specimens by Openstax, licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Light detection and ranging (LiDAR) has become becomes / has become / became an essential technology for automated applications, from robotics to driverless cars. These systems typically rely rely / have relied / relied on laser scanning to recover position information. Here, we propose propose / have proposed / will propose a hybrid LiDAR approach which combines combines / has combined / combined a multi-view camera system for position and distance information with a simple scannerless LiDAR system for velocity tracking and depth accuracy. We show show / have shown / will show that it is possible to create  a compound image of a scene at more than 1 frame per second and with depth accuracy of 2.5 cm or better. Our hybrid approach avoids avoids / has avoided / avoided the need for bulky and expensive scanning systems, while supplying additional velocity information. We hope that this solution will provide has provided / will provide / may provide a simpler, more robust alternative to 3D scanning systems for autonomous vehicles.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Reference words

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

Reference words usually replace nouns, but can also refer back to whole clauses, sentences, and parts of text. 

 We usually use this/these at the start of a sentence to add new information to a topic begun in a previous sentence.

  • That/those is more emphatic, and is often used to differentiate one thing from another.
  • We often use that/those + of + noun to avoid repeating a previous noun in the same structure.
  • We can use it to refer to something we have just mentioned. The plural of it as the subject of a sentence is The plural of it as the object of a sentence is them.
  • One(s) can be used to replace countable nouns. Do not end sentences with one(s). Repeat the noun if necessary.
  • .. the other are used to add information about two things mentioned previously. When there are more than two things in the list, use one... another.
  • The former refers to the first of two mentioned things, the latter to the second. It is advisable to use the latter... the former only to avoid significant repetition. Otherwise, use a synonym or repeat the noun for clarity.

 Ensure that it is always clear what reference words refer to. If necessary, repeat the noun or use a synonym.

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible

Exercise 2
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Choose the correct sentence for each gap in the text.

What is the Microbiome?

The human microbiome is composed of communities of bacteria (as well as viruses and fungi) that have greater complexity than the human genome itself. Large-scale metagenomic projects (community and environmental genomics), such as the European Metagenomics of the Human Intestinal Tract and the Human Microbiome Project, have reported 3.3 million unique protein-encoding genes, as compared with the entire human genome which has around 23 000 genes. These studies have described the beneficial functions of the normal gut microbiota on health down to the genetic level.

The human microbiome has an extensive range of functions, such as developing immunity and defending against pathogens. It also plays a role in host nutrition, including the production of short-chain fatty acids, synthesis of vitamins, and fat storage.

Recent investigations suggest that the microbiome can have a major impact on cognitive functions and behavior patterns, such as social interaction and stress management. This makes it an essential organ of the body, without which we could not function correctly.

Microbiome composition

A healthy human gut can house at least 1000 different species of bacteria, comprising of two major phyla, Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes. Other microbes also live in the gut,  including viruses, fungi, and archaea. However, there has been little research on those compared to bacteria.

The human microbiome and disease

The relationship between changes in microbiome composition and disease pathogenesis is uncertain. The challenge is to identify whether microbial imbalance is related to disease, sometimes termed ‘dysbiosis,’ and to be able to distinguish between cause and effect. However, manipulation of the microbiota for therapeutic purposes is a rapidly advancing area of research. Some of the approaches currently being investigated include targeting antibiotic treatments to eliminate select microbiota, using probiotics and prebiotics to stimulate the growth of beneficial bacteria, and transplanting fecal microbiota to restore bacterial communities.  Studying the composition of the microbiome in healthy individuals is important to understand the effect that these therapies may have on human health and susceptibility to disease.

Adapted from 'What is the Microbiome?' by Protima Amon and Ian Sanderson , licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

The passive is formed using the verb to be in the correct form + the past participle of the main verb.

If the same object is used for more than one passive verb, the object and the verb to be can be omitted, like this:

  • Example: 'The sample was weighed, then the sample was heated and the sample was stirred.'

If the same passive verb is used for more than one object, then both the verb to be and the past participle can be omitted, like this:

  • Example: 'We determined the size, we determined the shape, and we determined the weight of the object.'
Cloze Activity
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Complete the text with the passive forms of the verbs in brackets.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

The sugar beet pulp was analyzed following methods recommended for the sugar industry. The amount of solid substance were weighed (weigh) in a Radwag WPS-30S weighing dryer. Reducing sugars and total sugars (after inversion with hydrochloric acid) were evaluated (evaluate) according to the Miller method, in g of invert sugar per kg of thick juice. The concentration of saccharose was calculated (calculate) as the difference between the quantities of total sugars and reducing sugars (with a conversion coefficient of 0.95). Cellulose content was determined (determine) according to the Kürschner-Hoffer method, hemicellulose content  was analyzed (analyse) using the Ernakow method, and lignin content was quantified (quantify) following the method recommended by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL). The pH was measured (measure) using a digital pH meter.

Adapted from Joanna Berłowska, Katarzyna Pielech-Przybylska, Maria Balcerek, Urszula Dziekońska-Kubczak, Piotr Patelski, Piotr Dziugan, Dorota Kręgiel, "Simultaneous Saccharification and Fermentation of Sugar Beet Pulp for Efficient Bioethanol Production", BioMed Research International, vol. 2016, Article ID 3154929, 10 pages, 2016. https://doi.org/10.1155/2016/3154929  (CC BY 0.4)
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Hydrophobized flax fibers

Flax short fibers were functionalized (functionalize) using chlorotris(trimethylsiloxy)silane (CTS) in pyridine as a solvent. To functionalize 1 g of flax fibers, 1 mL of CTS and 5 mL pyridine were put (put) into a sealed 50 mL falcon tube with nitrogen-enriched atmosphere and thoroughly mixed (mix). The slurry was shaken (shake) for 10 min and dispersed (disperse) in an ultrasonic bath for 20 min. The fibers were filtered (filter) and washed (wash) with 60 mL of double distilled H2O. The fibers were dried (dry) at 50 °C under reduced pressure and sifted (sift) through a 280-μm sieve.

Adapted from Schaffner, M., Faber, J.A., Pianegonda, L. et al. 3D printing of robotic soft actuators with programmable bioinspired architectures. Nat Commun 9, 878 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-018-03216-w (CC BY 0.4)

Hydrophobized flax fibers

Flax short fibers were functionalized (functionalize) using chlorotris(trimethylsiloxy)silane (CTS) in pyridine as a solvent. To functionalize 1 g of flax fibers, 1 mL of CTS and 5 mL pyridine were put (put) into a sealed 50 mL falcon tube with nitrogen-enriched atmosphere and thoroughly mixed (mix). The slurry was shaken (shake) for 10 min and dispersed (disperse) in an ultrasonic bath for 20 min. The fibers were filtered (filter) and washed (wash) with 60 mL of double distilled H2O. The fibers were dried (dry) at 50 °C under reduced pressure and sifted (sift) through a 280-μm sieve.

Adapted from Schaffner, M., Faber, J.A., Pianegonda, L. et al. 3D printing of robotic soft actuators with programmable bioinspired architectures. Nat Commun 9, 878 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-018-03216-w (CC BY 0.4)

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Use cautious language to avoid simplification, generalization, and sounding overconfident. However, do not use cautious language unnecessarily. Examples of cautious language include:

  2. Our results might may / might  lead  to  the  conclusion  that methanol  fuels do not pose a serious environmental risk.  Excessive complacency,  however,  is

  4. Further research could can / could reveal more about the origin of these features.

  6. This result appears to appears to / tends to confirm our hypothesis.

  9. It is possible possible / probable, but unlikely, that this was due to a placebo effect.

Compound nouns and adjectives

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

Compound nouns are sometimes one word, like database, or two words, like computer science. If two or more words are used to modify a noun (or a compound noun) they may be joined with a hyphen, as in billion-dollar particle collider. This is known as a compound adjective.

The first part of a compound noun or adjective is usually singular, even if it refers to something plural:

  •  Engines for cars: Car engines.

However, in some cases the noun modifier remains plural. Sometimes it is important to stress that the noun modifier refers to more than one thing. Sometimes the original noun is used most commonly or only in the plural. Sometimes the two versions are interchangeable. For example:

  •  Skills training: more than one skill will be taught.
  • Data analyst: the singular form datum is rare.
  • System(s) administrator: the s is optional.

When forming a compound noun, any implied prepositions, verbs, articles, pronouns, or nouns are omitted:

  • A printer that enables the fabrication of objects in 3D: a 3D printer.

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible

If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
